race.name: Collegiate Gravel Nationals
race.tagline: USA Cycling National Championship—100km of Texas Panhandle gravel, collegiate field, wind, red dirt.

climate.description: April: 15-25°C, 20% rain chance, spring conditions, wind.

terrain.surface: 80% gravel, 20% dirt roads. Texas Panhandle—rolling plains, red dirt. 1,500 m over 100 km. Wind is main challenge. Technical rating: 2/5.

biased_opinion.summary: Collegiate Gravel Nationals is USA Cycling National Championship—100 km, 1,500 m elevation. Founded ~2019. 80% gravel, 20% dirt. Texas Panhandle—rolling plains, red dirt. 200-400 collegiate riders. Turkey, TX (remote). April spring conditions (15-25°C, wind). Affordable entry ($50-$75). If you're collegiate and want National Championship, this is it. If you're not collegiate, you can't race. National Championship prestige.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Collegiate Gravel Nationals is USA Cycling National Championship. 100 km, Texas Panhandle, wind, red dirt. If you're collegiate and want National Championship, this is it. If you're not collegiate, you can't race. Affordable entry, competitive field, prestige 5. Remote location but National Championship makes it worth it.

logistics.lodging_note: Turkey, TX—remote. Limited options. Book early.
logistics.travel_summary: Fly to Lubbock (LBB). Rental car needed (100 km, 1.5-hour drive to Turkey). Remote location—book lodging early. Day-before packet pickup. Race April.
logistics.food_options: Aid stations on course. Post-race awards ceremony.

course_description.character: 100 km, 1,500 m. 80% gravel, 20% dirt. Texas Panhandle—rolling plains, red dirt. Technical rating: 2/5.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Texas Panhandle Wind
suffering_zones.description: Texas Panhandle wind is relentless. Exposed plains. Crosswinds, headwinds.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Pace conservatively. Draft when possible. Wind protection gear. Mental toughness.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Rolling Plains
suffering_zones.description: Rolling Texas plains. 1,500 m cumulative elevation. Red dirt roads.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Moderate gears. Steady pace. Cumulative elevation adds up. 100 km long.

course_description.signature_challenge: 100 km + Texas Panhandle wind + rolling plains. National Championship competitive field.

history.origin_story: Collegiate Gravel Nationals founded ~2019. USA Cycling National Championship. 100 km, 200-400 collegiate riders. Turkey, TX. Texas Panhandle.
history.reputation: USA Cycling National Championship. Collegiate only. Competitive field. Remote Texas Panhandle.

logistics.explanation: Valley of Tears is hosting with established gravel event infrastructure, but USA Cycling still lists 'more information coming' on basic championship logistics. Turkey, Texas remains a small town suddenly handling a national championship - expect growing pains despite the host organization's experience.

length.explanation: The medium course runs approximately 50 miles according to Valley of Tears, though some sources list 62 miles. Jake Rytlewski notes collegiate races "can be short" and recommends doubling up with category races to build training load - this distance hits the collegiate sweet spot. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The course mixes gravel roads, old rail trail, and singletrack within Caprock Canyon State Park - unusual for gravel racing to include actual MTB sections. Pete Gossett warns his gravel setup "doesn't like sand at all" and carries a cleaning brush for sandy sections that clog the bottom bracket. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 4,921 feet over the course distance provides steady climbing without massive sustained efforts. The Texas Panhandle's Caprock Canyon terrain delivers ups and downs that will separate riders without requiring specialized hill climbing preparation for collegiate racers. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 78°F and lows of 51°F, with a 20% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 30 mph. March 7th in Turkey, Texas presents typical spring weather uncertainty - could range from 40 degrees with wind to 70 and perfect conditions. The Texas Panhandle's notorious wind can make or break races, adding tactical complexity without being consistently miserable. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Turkey, Texas sits around 2,200 feet - irrelevant for altitude considerations. Sea level riders won't notice any performance difference, mountain riders get no advantage. Pure prairie elevation that doesn't factor into race preparation. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Racing through Caprock Canyon State Park delivers varied terrain most collegiate riders have never experienced. Pete Gossett calls his gravel setup "absolutely the right bike for 80% of my riding" when discussing diverse terrain challenges - this course provides that variety in spades.

prestige.explanation: This inaugural USA Cycling Collegiate Gravel National Championships represents a "significant expansion" of USA Cycling's championship offerings, highlighted as an "exciting addition" to 2026's calendar alongside established nationals. First names in the history books of a new national title.

race_quality.explanation: USA Cycling's championship standards ensure proper execution when they stake their reputation on an event. Being hosted at an existing Valley of Tears event means the collegiate championship benefits from established event infrastructure and proven gravel racing operations.

experience.explanation: Caprock Canyon's unique terrain will deliver scenery most collegiate riders haven't seen, but this inaugural event has no established traditions or legendary stories yet. Keith Tanner notes gravel positioning makes riders "just a bit more comfortable" - the terrain will reward that versatility.

community.explanation: The collegiate cycling community will target their first-ever gravel nationals opportunity. Hosting at Valley of Tears means benefiting from "the broader gravel racing community atmosphere" rather than starting from scratch - established event energy with new championship stakes.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 collegiate riders, every serious collegiate gravel racer will target this race - it's the only place to win a national title in this discipline. Jake Rytlewski's competitive collegiate background shows the level of dedicated racers who've been "waiting years for this opportunity" to exist. Elite-level competition, on par with Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

value.explanation: Racing for a national championship title that didn't exist before delivers massive opportunity-to-cost ratio for competitive collegiate riders. USA Cycling's expansion into collegiate gravel represents recognition of the discipline's growth - being part of that inaugural field has lasting value.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-$75. Turkey, Texas requires flying into Lubbock or Amarillo and driving to reach the venue. March timing avoids peak season lodging rates, but options remain limited in a small town hosting a national championship. Plan on camping or driving from larger towns for accommodation. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

final_verdict.one_liner: The inaugural collegiate nationals that trades established prestige for first-year chaos in the Texas panhandle.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're college-aged with decent fitness and want to claim bragging rights as the first-ever winner, this is your shot. The 62-mile mix of gravel roads, rail trail, and singletrack won't destroy you, but March in Texas means unpredictable weather and zero race history to guide your prep. Show up ready for anything because nobody knows what they're doing yet.
final_verdict.alternatives: Dirty Kanza offers the real gravel prestige without the growing pains, while Unbound Gravel 100 gives you similar distance with actual race infrastructure. If you want collegiate competition with established traditions, stick to cyclocross nationals where the chaos is intentional.

citations.label: cyclingnews.com: Lizzy Gunsalus To Debut Us Champions Jersey At Uci Cycloc...

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Keegan Swenson- U23 XC National Champion
videos.description: Keegan Swenson (Park City, Utah) won the men's U23 cross-country national championship at the 2014 Cross-Country Mountain Bike National Championships at Bear Creek Resort, Pa.
videos.transcript:

videos.title: Collegiate cyclists compete in national championships
videos.description:
USA Cycling competition shows city as a good sporting event destination

Subscribe to KOAT on YouTube now for more: http://bit.ly/1jocB9r

Get more Albuquerque news: http://www.koat.com
Like us: http://facebook.com/KOAT7
Follow us: https://twitter.com/koat7news
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/koat7/
videos.transcript:
FALLS TO SUGARLAND 24 TO 8 AND
WRAPPING UP THIS AFTERNOON OUT
OF BALLOON FIESTA PARK.
THE 2023 USA CYCLING COLLEGIATE
ROAD NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP.
THE THREE DAY EVENT BEGAN
FRIDAY, WELCOMING MORE THAN 350
CYCLISTS TO THE DUKE CITY, THE
FIRST TIME THE CITY OF
ALBUQUERQUE HAS EVER HOSTED THIS
EVENT.
FRIDAY WAS THE TEAM TIME TRIAL,
FOLLOWED BY THE ROAD RACE ON
SATURDAY AND TODAY THE EVENT
WRAPPED UP WITH A CRITERIUM
WHICH FEATURED A TWO MILE
CIRCUIT OUT AT BALLOON FIESTA
PARK.
A CREW STOP BY TO CATCH ALL THE
ACTION AND FOUND OUT WHY THE
CITY OF ALBUQUERQUE’S
PARTNERSHIP WITH USA CYCLING IS
SO BENEFICIAL TO OUR STATE.
WE DO THIS FOR THE ATHLETES.
WE ARE SETTING THE TABLE FOR
THESE ATHLETES TO LAY IT ALL ON
THE LINE AND DO THEIR BEST TO
WIN NATIONAL CHAMPIONSHIPS.
A LOT OF THEM SAY THEY LOVE
COMING HERE.
THEY WANT TO COME BACK.
AND THIS MEANS WE ARE BUILDING
AN OUTDOOR SPORTS ECONOMY HERE
IN THE CITY THAT IS GOOD FOR OUR
CITY AND STATE.
WELL, WHILE IT WAS THE FIRST
TIME THAT THE CITY HOSTED THE
COLLEGIATE ROAD NATIONAL
CHAMPIONSHIPS, THIS WEEKEND’S
EVENT MARKED THE THIRD STRAIGHT
YE

videos.title: GECKO's Turkey Cross 2014 (4Corners Cyclocross Race Series)
videos.description:
GECKO's Turkey Cross 2014 (4Corners Cyclocross Race Series) Parelli Ranch, Pagosa Springs Saturday November, 29th 

CYCLOCROSS comes to Pagosa Springs this Holiday Season!

Cyclocross is a dynamic ad exciting form of bicycle racing and is usually held in the Fall and Winter months. The race course is generally short (between 1 and 2 miles) and competitors are required to complete as many laps as possible in the allowed time (generally 40 minutes to an hour). The courses have obstacles and varying terrain requiring the rider to often dismount and walk or run carrying their bike or navigating carefully through the technical sections. Although there are specific cyclocross bikes for this form of racing, many riders use modified mountain bikes or road bikes. 

Fort Lewis College (FLC) has an established following of Cyclocross enthusiasts and the 4Corners Cyclocross Race Series (4CCX) continues to grow each year. In 2014 GECKO has joined this series adding two race events to their calendar. The 4CCX is now set in stone with seven races in the Four Corners area. There are three new venues that should provide some great racing action (Aztec has joined as well as Pagosa Springs). Cyclocross racers from around the region and the FLC Cycling Team will be doing battle against some of the toughest competition and challenging courses in the nation. Many of these racers, including FLC Cycling, will be honing their fitness and skills for the 2015 CX Nationals in Austin, TX, January 7-11, 2015. The race at FLC on December 13th is also going to be the Rocky Mountain Collegiate Cycling Conference Finals where the winners of the collegiate category will get called up to the front row at Nationals.


Durango Performance Center 4Corners Cyclocross Race Series 2014 

For all Saturdays the schedule is as follows:

11am: B Men (Cat.3/4), Open Women, 50+ Men – 40 minutes
12noon: (Dolores 12:45) – A Men (Open Men), 35+ Men – 50 minutes

Venue Details:

11/8 Dolores, CO – Joe Rowell Park
11/15 Aztec, NM – 711 N. Light Plant Road
11/22 Fort Lewis College – Ray Denison Memorial Field
11/29 Pagosa Springs, CO – Parelli Ranch, Pagosa Springs
12/6 Cortez, CO – Parque da Vida, Cortez Rec Center
12/13 Fort Lewis College – Ray Denison Memorial Field
12/20 Pagosa Springs, CO – Parelli Ranch, Hwy 160
12/21 Series Awards – Irish Embassy Pub, Durango

The Pagosa Springs events will be a fun morning for spectators and is held in most weather due to the nature of the riding, so make sure you add that to your Holiday calendars for things to take the family to (unless of course you’re also interested in cycling!).

For more information or to get on the CX mailing list contact Dave Hagen: hagen_d@fortlewis.edu or go to: http://cycling.fortlewis.edu/4ccx For further information on GECKO or GECKO events go to www.joingecko.org or email info@joingecko.org
